title: Kiwi Rugby World Cup referee criticised for giving Fiji player 'low five' against Wallabies
text:
New Zealand referee Ben O'Keeffe has found himself in hot water after footage emerged of him offering a 'low-five' during Saturday's match between Fiji and Australia.

Full-back Kini Murimurivalu had just scored a try to extend Fiji's lead to 21-12 against the Wallabies, when O'Keeffe extended his right arm and offered a 'low-five' to the Fijian before the conversion.

Murimurivalu duly obliged, and the Super Rugby referee now faces criticism for his action, especially given his performance was already under the spotlight following Reece Hodge's citing for a dangerous tackle, which went unpunished during the game.

Referee Ben O'Keeffe (orange shirt) extends his right arm towards Fiji's Kini Murimurivalu

O'Keeffe gives a low-five to Murimurivalu who obligingly returns the favour in Sapporo

The gesture took place just after a Fiji try and before the subsequent conversion attempt

The try was Fiji's last points scored of the match, as Australia mounted a late comeback to claim a bonus-point win, 39-21, at the Sapporo Dome.

But the main talking point came in the first half, as Fiji's star flanker Peceli Yato was substituted after being hit with a 'no-arms' tackle by Australia's Hodge.

No action was taken at the time by O'Keeffe for the shoulder smash , but Hodge has been cited and could miss the rest of the tournament if he is found guilty of reckless contact.

O'Keeffe was taking charge of his first Rugby World Cup match in Sapporo on Saturday

O'Keeffe has refereed on the international stage since 2016, and this is his first Rugby World Cup.

He referees in the southern hemisphere's Super Rugby competition, and has caused a stir in the Australian media for his gesture on Saturday.

Fiji, who are in Pool D alongside the Aussies, Wales, Uruguay and Georgia, next play on Wednesday against Uruguay, while Australia's next match is against Wales on Sunday in Tokyo.
